In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When you buy or sell a stock, the dividend payment is made directly to you, the investor, and you are responsible for paying any taxes on the dividend income.

The dividend quote you receive will show the amount of the dividend payment, but it will not include any withholding taxes that may be deducted by the company paying the dividend. It is important to note that dividend payments are subject to federal income tax, as well as state and local taxes, depending on where you reside.

To calculate your after-tax dividend income, you will need to factor in the withholding taxes that are deducted from the dividend payment. You can use the following formula to calculate your after-tax dividend income:

After-tax dividend income = Dividend payment - Withholding taxes

For example, let's say you receive a dividend payment of $100 and the withholding tax rate is 25%. Your after-tax dividend income would be:

After-tax dividend income = $100 - $25 = $75

It is important to keep in mind that the withholding tax rate may vary depending on the company paying the dividend, as well as your
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access. The National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA) rules allow financial institutions to revoke their authorization for ACH transactions at any time.

To block previously authorized ACH access, the financial institution must provide written notice to the originator of the ACH transactions, stating the reason for the revocation and the effective date of the revocation. The notice must be provided at least one business day before the effective date of the revocation.

Once the revocation notice is provided, the originator of the ACH transactions must stop initiating any further ACH transactions through the previously authorized ACH access. The financial institution may also require the originator to provide a new authorization for future ACH transactions.

It's important to note that once an ACH access is revoked, the originator cannot simply create a new ACH access to continue the same transactions. The originator must obtain a new authorization from the financial institution, which may involve providing updated information and completing a new authorization process.

In addition, financial institutions may have their own policies and procedures for revoking ACH access, so it's important to check with your financial institution for their specific requirements and procedures.

Overall, while it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access, it's important to follow the proper procedures and provide timely notice to the origin

2. Tourism: A weak CAD can make travel to Canada more attractive to foreign tourists, leading to increased tourism revenue and job creation in the sector.
3. Real estate: A low CAD can make Canadian real estate more attractive to foreign investors, leading to increased demand and higher property prices.
4. Dividend-paying stocks: Many Canadian companies pay dividends in Canadian dollars, so a low CAD can increase the purchasing power of these dividends for Canadian investors.

Negative impacts:

1. Import costs: A low CAD can make imports cheaper, but it can also increase the cost of goods and services that are imported, such as fuel, electronics, and food. This can lead to higher inflation and reduced purchasing power for Canadian consumers.
2. Travel: A weak CAD can make travel to the United States and other countries more expensive for Canadian tourists, as they will have to pay more
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss is a risk management tool used by investors to limit their potential losses in a trading position. It is a hedging strategy that involves selling a security at a specified price (stop price) to limit potential losses. The stop-loss order becomes a market order once the security reaches the stop price, and the broker will sell the security at the current market price.

Using stop-loss as risk management can be safe when implemented correctly. Here are some benefits of using stop-loss:

1. Protects against unexpected price movements: Stop-loss orders can help protect against unexpected price movements that could result in significant losses. By setting a stop price, an investor can limit their potential losses to the amount of the stop price.
2. Flexibility: Stop-loss orders can be adjusted as market conditions change. For example, an investor can move the stop price higher or lower to reflect changing market conditions.
3. Emotional control: Using stop-loss orders can help investors avoid making emotional decisions based on short-term price movements. By setting a stop price, investors can automate their risk management strategy and avoid making impulsive decisions based on fear or greed.
4. Diversification: Stop-loss orders can be used in conjunction with other risk management strategies, such as diversification, to further reduce potential losses.

However, there
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

4. Carry forward excess losses: If the loss exceeds the amount of capital gains you have to offset, you can carry the excess loss forward to future years. You can use the excess loss to offset
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, a debt collector is legally allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report when attempting to collect a debt. A hard inquiry is a type of credit inquiry that appears on your credit report and indicates that a lender or debt collector has accessed your credit report to evaluate your creditworthiness.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), debt collectors are considered "creditors" and are allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt. This means that if you have an outstanding debt with a collector, they may check your credit report to determine your creditworthiness and determine the best course of action for collecting the debt.

It's important to note that debt collectors are only allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt, and they are not allowed to use the information in your credit report for any other purpose. Additionally, debt collectors are required to follow the FCRA's requirements for making hard inquiries, which include:

* Identifying themselves as debt collectors and providing their name and address
* Informing you that a hard inquiry will be made on your credit report
* Providing you with the name and address of the credit reporting agency that will make the inquiry

If a deb
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

It is a limit order that is triggered when the security reaches the stop price, but the trade is only executed at the limit price or better. For example, if you place a stop limit order to buy stock XYZ at $50 with a limit price of $55, your order will only be executed at $55 or higher. answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

Related hedges are financial instruments used to manage risks associated with specific investments or market conditions. These hedges are designed to offset potential losses or gains in a portfolio by taking a position in a security or asset that is negatively correlated with the original investment. In other words, when the value of the underlying investment increases, the value of the hedge asset decreases, and vice versa.

There are several types of related hedges, including:

1. Long/Short Equity: This involves taking a long position in a security or asset and a short position in a security or asset that is negatively correlated with the original investment. For example, an investor may take a long position in a stock and a short position in a put option on the same stock to hedge against potential losses.
2. pairs trading: This involves taking a long position in two securities that have a historical correlation of -1 and taking a short position in two securities that have a historical correlation of +1. For example, an investor may take a long position in Company A and a short position in Company B, as long as Company A and Company B have a historical correlation of -1.
3. Index hedging: This involves taking a long position in an index or a basket of securities and a short position in a hedged index or a basket of

answers: Current account offers a lot of benefits for sole proprietors. Think of it like bank account for a company. The bank provides a host of facilities for the company. A sole proprietor does not have enough value as that of a company for a bank but needs similar services. Thus Indian banks offer a toned down version of the account offered to a company. Current account offer very good overdraft ( withdrawing money even if balance is zero). This feature is very useful as  business cycles and payment schedules can be different for each supplier/customer the sole proprietor does business with. Imagine the sole proprietor account has balance of zero on day 0. customer X made payment by cheque on day 1. Cheques will get credited only on Day 3 (Assume Day 2 is a national holiday or weekend).  Sole proprietor gave a cheque to his supplier on day 0. The supplier deposited the cheque on Day 0 and the sole proprietor's bank will debit the the proprietor's account on day 1. As customer's cheque will get credited only day 3, the overdraft facility will let the proprietor borrow from the bank Interestingly, current accounts were offered long before Indian banks started  offering customized accounts to corporate customers. The payment schedule mentioned in my example is based on a clearing system > 10 years ago. Systems have become much simpler now but banks have always managed to offer something significantly extra on lines similar to my example above to proprietor over a savings bank account

Why would a central bank or country not want their currency to appreciate against other currencies?[/INST]
pred:
There are several reasons why a central bank or country may not want their currency to appreciate against other currencies:

1. Export Competitiveness: If a currency appreciates too much, it can make a country's exports more expensive for foreign buyers, which can lead to a decrease in demand and a negative impact on the country's trade balance. This can be particularly problematic for countries that rely heavily on exports for their economic growth.
2. Inflation: A strong currency can lead to higher import prices, which can drive up inflation. If a country's central bank is trying to combat inflation, a strong currency can make it more difficult to achieve this goal.
3. Capital Flows: A strong currency can also attract capital flows from other countries, which can lead to a depreciation of the currency's value. This can be problematic for countries that are trying to manage their currency's value and maintain a stable economic environment.
4. Economic Growth: A strong currency can make a country's goods and services more expensive for foreigners, which can lead to a decrease in demand and a negative impact on economic growth.
5. Political Stability: A strong currency can also lead to political instability, as a country's leaders may be seen as ineffective or unable to manage the economy if the currency continues to appreciate.
6. Currency Wars: A strong currency

Similarly the imports from these countires to China would be more expensive.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Does home equity grow with the investment put into the house?[/INST]
pred:
Home equity refers to the value of ownership that a homeowner has in their property, which is calculated by subtracting the amount owed on the mortgage from the market value of the property. While home equity can increase over time as the value of the property appreciates, it does not directly grow with the investment put into the house.

Home equity is determined by the market value of the property and the outstanding balance of the mortgage. For example, if a house is worth $500,000 and the homeowner owes $200,000 on their mortgage, the home equity would be $300,000 ($500,000 - $200,000).

However, the value of the property can increase over time due to various factors such as appreciation, renovations, and location. For instance, if the property appreciates by 5% per year, the value of the property would increase from $500,000 to $520,000 after two years, which would increase the home equity to $320,000 ($520,000 - $200,000).

It's important to note that home equity is not the same as the value of the investment put into the house.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the potential for future equity ownership. While they share some similarities, there are also some key differences between these instruments.

Convertible debt is a type of debt security that can be converted into a predetermined number of shares of the issuer's common stock at a later date, usually at the investor's option. This means that the investor has the potential to benefit from any increase in the stock price, while still receiving regular interest payments like a traditional bond.

Notes, on the other hand, are similar to bonds but are typically unsecured and have a longer maturity date. They may also offer a fixed or floating interest rate, and may have a call feature that allows the issuer to redeem the notes at a specified price.

Bonds are a type of debt security that pays a fixed rate of interest and returns the principal amount to the investor at maturity. They are typically issued by companies or governments to raise capital for a specific purpose, such as financing a new project or refinancing existing debt.

Debentures are a type of long-term debt instrument that is unsecured and does not carry any collateral. They are typically issued by companies to raise capital and pay
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

answers: There are certain situations where you could legally pay yourself rent, but it'd be in the context of multiple business entities interacting, never in the context of an individual renting their own property.  Even if you could, any rent paid to yourself would count as rental income, so there'd be no benefit. Edit: I was hunting for examples where it might be acceptable, and didn't, but I found a good explanation as to why it is not acceptable from Brandon Hall on a BiggerPockets post: To get technical, you will be going up against the Economic Substance   Doctrine which states that a transaction has economic substance if:   (1) the transaction changes in a meaningful way (apart from Federal   income tax effects) the taxpayer’s economic position; and (2) the   taxpayer has a substantial purpose (apart from Federal income tax   effects) for entering into such transaction. By transferring your primary residence into a LLC, you would not be   changing your economic position. Further, you do not have a   substantial purpose for entering into such transaction other than to   simply avoid paying federal income taxes. So it might make sense if multiple people owned the LLC that owned the property you wanted to rent, and there are instances where company X owns holding company Y that owns an office building that company X rents space in. But if you're the sole player in the LLC's then it sounds like a no-go.

Interest on Amount Exceeding CC Balance?[/INST]
pred:
Interest on an amount exceeding your credit card balance is a common occurrence when carrying a balance on your credit card. This is known as "deferred interest" or "interest on interest." Here's how it works:

When you make a purchase with your credit card, the amount is added to your balance. If you don't pay off the entire balance by the due date, interest is charged on the remaining balance. However, if the amount of interest charged exceeds the amount of your credit card balance, you may be subject to deferred interest.

Deferred interest occurs when you carry a balance on your credit card for a certain period of time, typically several months or a year. During this time, interest is charged on the outstanding balance, but the interest charges are deferred or delayed. This means that the interest charges are not added to your balance until the deferment period ends.

For example, let's say you have a credit card balance of $1,000 and your credit card has a deferment period of 18 months. During this time, interest is charged on the $1,000 balance, but the interest charges are not added to your balance. After the deferment period ends, the interest charges are added to your balance, and you will be responsible for paying the accumulated interest.

It's important to note that deferred interest can be cost
answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

Why there's always a very huge volume of trades for AAPL every day before market close?[/INST]
pred:
The high volume of trades in Apple Inc. (AAPL) stock before market close is primarily due to the natural flow of trading activity in the stock market. Here are some factors that contribute to this phenomenon:

1. Investor sentiment: Investors often make decisions based on short-term market trends and news. Before market close, investors may be more likely to buy or sell stocks, including AAPL, based on their expectations for the next day's price movement. This can lead to a surge in trading volume as investors try to capitalize on any potential price movements.
2. Options expiration: Apple has options contracts that expire every month, typically on the third Friday of the month. As these options approach their expiration date, there is often a flurry of trading activity as investors buy or sell options contracts to manage their positions before the contracts expire. This can result in higher trading volume in the days leading up to options expiration.
3. Institutional trading: Institutional investors, such as hedge funds and mutual funds, often trade large blocks of stocks before market close. These trades can be driven by various factors, including portfolio rebalancing, risk management, or market-timing strategies. As these investors execute their trades, they can contribute to higher trading volumes.
answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Even just in its introduction this paper (PDF) gives a fair overview of other reasons why there's a lot of trading at end-of-day in general. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

Can an ETF perform differently than its holdings?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, an ETF (Exchange-Traded Fund) can perform differently than its holdings in several ways. Here are some key reasons why:

This is because ETFs are actively managed, and the fund manager may make changes to the portfolio to better align with the investment strategy or to rebalance the portfolio.

4. Creations and redemptions: ETFs are created and redeemed through a process called creation and redemption, which involves the transfer of securities between the ETF and its authorized participants. This process can impact the ETF's performance, as it may not reflect the exact performance of the underlying assets.
5. Leverage: Some E
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

When someone starts a bank, they normally get together a bunch of investors -- perhaps people they know personally, perhaps they sell stock -- to raise initial capital. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

Sure, I'd be happy to help!

UK Gilts are government bonds issued by the British government to raise funds for various purposes. The interest rates and repayments on these bonds work as follows:

Interest Rates:
Gilts are issued with a fixed interest rate, which is set at the time of issuance and remains the same throughout the life of the bond. The interest rate is usually set above the inflation rate to compensate investors for the risk of inflation eroding their purchasing power. For example, if the inflation rate is 2%, the interest rate on a gilt might be set at 3% to provide a real return of 1% above inflation.

Repayment:
Gilts are repaid to investors at the end of their maturity period, which can range from 5 to 40 years. The repayment amount is calculated by multiplying the face value of the bond (the amount borrowed by the government) by a factor called the "yield to maturity." The yield to maturity takes into account the interest rate, inflation, and the time remaining until maturity.

For example, if a gilt has a face value of £1,000 and a 10-year maturity, and the yield to maturity is 3%, the repayment
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

answers: A UTMA may or may not fit your situation. The main drawbacks to a UTMA account is that it will count against your child for financial aid (it counts as the child's asset). The big downside to the 529 is the 10% penalty if the money isn't used for higher education. In the United States, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) considers gifts to be taxable income for the recipient when they are given in cash or in kind, and the value of the gift exceeds $15,000 in a single year. This threshold is known as the "annual gift tax exclusion."

Gifts that are below the annual gift tax exclusion do not have to be reported to the IRS, and they do not reduce the recipient's taxable income. However, if the value of the gifts exceeds the exclusion amount, the recipient may be required to file a gift tax return and pay gift tax.

It's important to note that the annual gift tax exclusion is per donor, per recipient, and applies to gifts made to any number of recipients. For example, if you give $15,000 to your spouse, $15,000 to your child, and $15,000 to your parent, you have not exceeded the annual gift tax exclusion, even though you have given a total of $45,000 in gifts.

Gifts that are not subject to gift tax include:

* Gifts to a spouse (or a spouse's family)
* Gifts to a charity
* Gifts to a political

This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual". If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. prompt:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs/mutual funds, and other securities. The wash sale rule is a tax provision that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of a security if they have purchased a substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale. However, the rule applies differently to different types of securities.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is straightforward. If you sell a stock at a loss and buy the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days before or after the sale, you will be deemed to have sold the replacement stock at its fair market value, which can result in the disallowance of the loss. However, if you buy a different stock that is not substantially identical, the wash sale rule does not apply.

For ETFs/mutual funds, the wash sale rule is more complex. The rule applies to the underlying securities of the ETF or mutual fund, rather than the ETF or mutual fund itself. So, if you sell an ETF or mutual fund that holds a security that you bought or sold within 30 days, the wash sale rule may apply. However, if you sell an ETF or mutual fund that holds a different security than the one you sold within 30 days, the wash sale rule
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are related concepts in real estate investing.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is a financial metric used to estimate the potential return on investment for a real estate property. It is calculated by dividing the property's net operating income (NOI) by its purchase price or market value. The resulting percentage represents the annual return on investment, based on the income generated by the property. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and a purchase price of $1 million, the capitalization rate would be 10% ($100,000 / $1 million).

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric used to measure a company's profitability. It is calculated by dividing the company's net income by its revenue. The resulting percentage represents the percentage of revenue that the company retains as profit. For example, if a company has revenue of $100,000 and net income of $20,000, the net profit margin would be 20% ($20,000 / $100,000).

While both capitalization rate and net profit margin are important metrics for real estate investors, they serve different purposes. Capitalization rate
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

prompt:

Where can I find definitive terms for a preferred share?[/INST]

Definitive terms for preferred shares can typically be found in the company's prospectus or offering document, which is filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) in the United States. The prospectus provides detailed information about the company, its financial condition, and the terms of the preferred shares being offered, including the following:

1. Dividend rate: The annual dividend rate paid on the preferred shares, expressed as a percentage of the par value of the shares.
2. Par value: The minimum amount that the company must pay to issue the preferred shares, which is typically $25 or $100 per share.
3. Convertibility: Whether the preferred shares are convertible into common shares, and the terms and conditions of conversion.
4. Voting rights: The extent to which the preferred shares are entitled to vote on certain matters, such as the election of directors or significant corporate actions.
5. Liquidation preference: The amount that the preferred shares are entitled to receive in the event of liquidation, dissolution, or winding up of the company, before any distribution is made to common shareholders.
6. Redeemability: Whether the preferred shares are redeemable by the company, and the terms and conditions of redemption.
7. Callability: Whether the company has the right to redeem the preferred shares at a specified price

prompt:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
A "lot" of EUR/USD is a standardized quantity of euros and US dollars that is used in the foreign exchange market. The size of a lot can vary depending on the broker or market, but the most common lots are:

* Micro lot: 1,000 units of the base currency (e.g. 1 lot of EUR/USD is 1,000 euros)
* Mini lot: 10,000 units of the base currency (e.g. 1 lot of EUR/USD is 10,000 euros)
* Standard lot: 100,000 units of the base currency (e.g. 1 lot of EUR/USD is 100,000 euros)

For example, if you want to trade EUR/USD with a standard lot size, you would need to have $100,000 in your account to execute a trade of 100,000 euros.

It's worth noting that the lot size you choose will affect your potential profit and loss, as well as your risk exposure. Trading with smaller lot sizes can help you manage your risk, but it may also limit your potential profits. On the other hand, trading with larger lot sizes can give
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) can be taxed as long-term capital gains in certain situations. RSUs are a type of equity compensation that employees receive in exchange for their service to a company. They represent the right to receive a specified number of shares of company stock at a later date, typically after a vesting period.

When an employee sells their RSUs, they are taxed as ordinary income, typically at the time of vesting. However, if the RSUs are held for more than one year after vesting, the gains on their sale are eligible for long-term capital gains treatment. This means that the employee will pay a lower tax rate on the gains, typically ranging from 0% to 20%, depending on their tax bracket.

To qualify for long-term capital gains treatment, the RSUs must be held for at least one year after vesting. If the RSUs are sold before the one-year holding period, the gains will be taxed as ordinary income. Additionally, if the employee receives a cash payment instead of stock, the RSUs will not be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment.

It's worth noting that the tax treatment of RSUs can vary depending on the specific terms of the award and the employee's individual circumstances.

Further, the company would withhold 25% of the VEST for federal taxes and 10% for state taxes, if I lived in a state with income tax. The withholding rate was flat, regardless of what my actual tax rate was. Capital gains on the change from the market value on the VEST date was calculated as short-term or long-term based on the time since the VEST date. A subsidy is a financial assistance provided by a government or organization to support a particular industry, product, or activity. The primary purpose of a subsidy is to reduce the cost of production or increase the demand for a particular good or service, with the aim of promoting economic growth, job creation, or social welfare.

Subsidies can take various forms, including direct payments, tax credits, or deductions. For example, a government may provide a direct payment to farmers to help them cover the cost of producing a certain crop, or it may offer a tax credit to companies that invest in research and development.

Subsidies can be used to support a wide range of industries and activities, including agriculture, energy, transportation, and education. They can also be targeted towards specific groups, such as small businesses or low-income households.

However, subsidies can also have potential drawbacks, such as distorting market prices, creating inefficiencies, or leading to overproduction. For example, if a government provides a subsidy to farmers to produce a certain crop, it may lead to an oversupply of that crop, which can then lead to lower prices and reduced profitability for farmers.

In addition, subsidies can create uneven competition, as companies that receive subsidies may have an
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

Yes, it is a bet on price fluctuations and against the house. A bet on a sports game, such as a football game, is a type of wager known as a "side bet." In a side bet, a bettor places a wager on the outcome of a game, such as the final score, the number of touchdowns scored, or the number of points scored by a particular team.

In a side bet, the bettor is essentially betting on the price fluctuations of the game, rather than the outcome of the game itself. The bettor is essentially predicting that the price of the game will move in a certain direction, such as the point spread increasing or decreasing. The bettor is then paid out based on the outcome of the game, regardless of the actual outcome.

For example, if a bettor places a side bet on the point spread of a football game, they are essentially betting that the point spread will increase. If the point spread does increase, the bettor will receive a payout based on the new point spread. If the point spread does not increase, the bettor will lose their bet.

EBITDA, or Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization, is a financial metric commonly used in business to measure a company's profitability. However, there isn't a direct equivalent of EBITDA in personal finance, as it is primarily used to evaluate a business's financial performance.

In personal finance, the focus is typically on managing individual expenses and income, rather than evaluating the profitability of a business. However, there are some financial metrics that can be used in a similar way to EBITDA in personal finance.

One such metric is "net income after taxes" (NIT). This represents the individual's total income after taxes, and can be used to evaluate their overall financial health. To calculate NIT, you would subtract taxes from total income.

Another metric that can be used in personal finance is "operating cash flow" (OCF). This represents the individual's cash inflows and outflows, excluding non-operating items such as investments or loans. OCF can be calculated by subtracting operating expenses from operating income.

While these metrics can provide some insight into an individual's financial health, they are not a direct equivalent of EBITDA. EBITDA is a more comprehensive metric that takes into account interest, taxes

Buying a motorcycle with a lien on it can be a complex decision, and whether it's a good or bad idea depends on various factors. A lien is a financial obligation or claim on a property, in this case, the motorcycle. When you buy a motorcycle with a lien, you are essentially borrowing money to purchase the vehicle, and the lender has a legal claim on the bike until the loan is paid off.

Here are some pros and cons to consider:

Pros:

1. Affordability: Buying a motorcycle with a lien may be more affordable than paying the full purchase price upfront. This can be especially beneficial for those who don't have the financial means to buy the bike outright.
2. Lower monthly payments: With a lien, the monthly payments may be lower compared to financing the entire purchase price. This can help you manage your budget and expenses better.
3. Flexibility: Some lenders may offer more flexible repayment terms or the option to make additional payments to pay off the lien earlier.

Cons:

1. Ownership issues: Until the loan is paid off, the lender has legal claim to the motorcycle. This means you may not have full ownership of the bike until the loan is satisfied.
2. Insurance
answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial trading strategy in which an investor sells a stock they do not own with the expectation of buying it back at a lower price to realize a profit. This is achieved by borrowing the stock from a broker or another investor and selling it at the current market price. The investor then buys back the stock at the lower price and returns it to the lender, pocketing the difference as profit.

Short selling is used to profit from a decline in the price of a stock, and it can also be used to hedge against potential losses in a long position. For example, an investor who owns a stock that they believe may decline in value can sell the stock short to offset potential losses in their long position.

It is important to note that short selling involves additional costs, such as the cost of borrowing the stock and any dividends or interest that may be paid out while the stock is being held. Additionally, short sellers are exposed to unlimited potential losses, as there is no limit to how high a stock can rise.

Short selling can be a complex and risky strategy, and it is not suitable for all investors. It is important to thoroughly understand the mechanics of short selling and the risks involved before attempting to use this strategy in your investment portfolio. It is also important to keep
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

Why would a tender offer be less than the market price?[/INST]

A tender offer is a financial transaction in which an investor or company purchases a large number of shares of a publicly traded company at a specified price. The tender offer price is typically lower than the current market price of the shares for several reasons:

1. Arbitrage opportunity: The investor or company making the tender offer may be able to purchase the shares at a lower price than the market price, with the intention of selling them at a profit after the tender offer is completed. This is known as an arbitrage opportunity.
2. Takeover bid: A tender offer may be part of a larger takeover bid, where the investor or company is attempting to acquire a controlling stake in the target company. In this case, the tender offer price may be lower than the market price to make the acquisition more attractive to shareholders.
3. Liquidation value: The tender offer price may be lower than the market price if the investor or company believes that the target company is undervalued and has a lower liquidation value than its market price.
4. Risk reduction: The tender offer price may be lower than the market price to reduce the risk of the investor or company. By purchasing a large number of shares at a lower price, the investor or company can reduce the potential loss if the market price of the shares declines.
5. Strategic reasons
answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. This is, however, usually not successful beyond the very short term, and typically only works because the company making a tender offer is the 800-pound gorilla, which can dictate its own terms with practically anyone else it meets. Such offers are also very closely watched by the SEC; if there's any hint that the larger company is acting in a predatory manner, or that its management is using the power and information of the company to profit themselves, the strategy will backfire as the larger company finds itself the target of SEC and DoJ legal proceedings.

This is known as "VAT relief" and is designed to help homeowners save money on their taxes.

Distinguishing between a gift and a payment for a service can be a bit tricky, but there are some key factors to consider. Here are some guidelines to help you make the distinction:

1. Intent: Consider the intent behind the transaction. If the person providing the service is doing so voluntarily and without expectation of payment, it is likely a gift. On the other hand, if the person is being paid for their services, it is a payment.
2. Value: Look at the value of the transaction. If the value of the service provided is minimal, it may be considered a gift. However, if the value of the service is significant, it is more likely to be considered a payment.
3. Relationship: Consider the relationship between the parties involved. If the parties have a personal or familial relationship, it is more likely to be considered a gift.
4. Documentation: Check if there is any documentation or agreement in place that outlines the terms of the transaction. If there is an agreement that outlines the payment terms, it is more likely to be considered a payment.
5. Tax implications: Consider the tax implications of the transaction. In many countries, gifts are not taxable, while payments for services are taxable.
6. Purpose: Consider the purpose of the transaction. If the transaction is for a personal or social purpose, it is more likely to be considered a gift
answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. If you do make a gift to an individual in excess of 14k, you'll need to file a gift tax return (IRS Form 709). When you file form 709, you won't need to pay taxes until the 5.34 million is exceeded. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

3. Strong fundamentals: In a stable economy, asset values are based on their underlying value and fundamentals, rather than speculative demand.

5. Strong financial regulation: In a stable economy, financial reg

Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

1. Co-signer's Credit Score: The co-signer's credit score plays a significant role in determining your loan terms and interest rate. If the co-signer has a poor credit score, it may be more difficult to qualify for a car loan, and you may end up with a higher interest rate. On the other hand, if the co-signer has a good credit score, you may be eligible for better loan terms.
2. Co-signer's Payment Responsibility: As the primary account holder, your co-signer is legally responsible for making the loan payments. This is why it's essential to have open and honest communication with your co-signer about your car loan obligations.
3. Shared Credit Utilization: When you and your co-signer share the same credit account, it can impact your credit utilization ratio. This is the percentage of your available credit that you're using. If you and your co-signer are both using a significant portion of your available credit, it can negatively affect your credit score.
answers: It sounds like your father got a loan and you are making the payments.  If your name and SSN are not on the loan then you are not getting credit for making the payments your father is.  So it will not affect your credit.  If you are on the loan as a secondary borrower it will affect your credit but not substantially on the positive but could affect it substantially on the negative side. Most states require that the primary signatory on a vehicle loan also be the primary owner on the title to the vehicle.  If your fathers name is the primary name on the title then you would have to retitle the car to refinance in your name.

3. Debt repayment: The company may be using its profits to repay debt or to reduce its debt-to-equity ratio, rather than distributing dividends to shareholders.

answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. However, there are some exceptions to this general rule. For example, if the class or business can demonstrate that the materials are being provided for use in a specific project or activity that is directly related to the instruction being provided, and the materials are not being resold or used for any other purpose, then they may not be subject to sales tax.

Additionally, some states may have specific exemptions or deductions available for certain types of businesses or activities, so it's worth exploring those options as well.

answers: In most jurisdictions, both the goods (raw materials) and the service (class) are being "sold" to the customer, who is the end user and thus the sale is subject to sales tax. So, when your friend charges for the class, that $100 is subject to all applicable sales taxes for the jurisdiction and all parent jurisdictions (usually city, county and state). The teacher should not have to pay sales tax when they buy the flowers from the wholesaler; most jurisdictions charge sales tax on end-user purchases only. However, they are required to have some proof of sales tax exemption for the purchase, which normally comes part and parcel with the DBA or other business entity registration paperwork in most cities/states.  Wholesalers deal with non-end-user sales (exempt from sales tax) all the time, but your average Michael's or Hobby Lobby may not be able to deal with this and may have to charge your friend the sales tax at POS. Depending on the jurisdiction, if this happens, your friend may be able to reduce the amount the customer is paying that is subject to sales tax by the pre-tax value of the materials the customer has paid for, which your friend already paid the tax on.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a formal process, known as negotiation. These instruments are typically issued by companies, governments, or other organizations and are designed to be traded on financial markets. Examples of negotiable securities include stocks, bonds, and mutual funds.

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives, which are financial instruments that derive their value from an underlying asset or event. Derivatives can be used to manage financial risk, speculate on price movements, or gain exposure to an underlying asset without actually owning it. Examples of derivatives include options, futures, and swaps.

The relationship between negotiable securities and derivatives is that derivatives can be used to gain exposure to the underlying asset of a negotiable security. For example, an investor may purchase a stock option that gives them the right to buy or sell a specific stock at a predetermined price. If the price of the underlying stock moves in the direction predicted by the investor, they can exercise the option and realize a profit. In this way, derivatives can be used to gain exposure to the underlying asset of a negotiable security, without actually owning the asset.

Another way that negotiable securities and derivatives are related is through the use of convertible securities. Convertible securities
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

prompt:

How does a TFSA work? Where does the interest come from?[/INST]
pred:
A Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a popular savings vehicle in Canada that allows individuals to save money without paying taxes on the interest earned. Here's how it works:

Contributions: You can contribute up to a certain amount each year to your TFSA, which is set by the government. The contribution limit for 2022 is $6,000. You can make withdrawals and recontribute the amount withdrawn at any time.

Growth: The interest earned on your TFSA investments is tax-free, meaning you won't pay taxes on the interest earned. The interest can come from investments such as stocks, bonds, mutual funds, and GICs.

Withdrawals: You can withdraw money from your TFSA at any time, and there are no penalties for withdrawing the principal amount or the interest earned. However, if you withdraw more than the annual contribution limit, you may be subject to a penalty.

Recontribution: You can recontribute withdrawn amounts to your TFSA at any time, including the year of withdrawal.

Investment options: Your TFSA can hold a wide range of investments, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, and GICs. You can also hold cash in your TFSA
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

When a debtor files for bankruptcy, the value of their assets at the time of filing determines the amount of assets that will be available to pay off creditors. This is known as the "bankruptcy value" of the assets.

In the United States, the Bankruptcy Code provides that assets are valued as of the date of the bankruptcy filing, not their current value. This means that if an asset has increased in value since the filing date, the debtor will not be able to use the higher current value to pay off creditors. Instead, the asset will be valued as of the filing date, and the debtor will be required to use the lower value to pay off creditors.

There are some exceptions to this general rule. For example, if an asset has been damaged or has decreased in value since the filing date, the debtor may be able to use the lower current value to pay off creditors. Additionally, if an asset is subject to a lien or other encumbrance, the value of the asset may be reduced to reflect the amount owed to the creditor.

4. Currency carry: Investing in currencies with higher interest rates than the investor's home country

There are several oversold indicators used in technical analysis to determine if a stock is oversold and by how much. Here are some commonly used equations:

1. Relative Strength Index (RSI): The RSI is a popular oversold indicator that measures the magnitude of recent price changes to determine if a stock is overbought or oversold. The RSI is calculated by dividing the average gain of up periods by the average loss of down periods over a given time frame, usually 14 days. An RSI reading below 30 indicates oversold conditions.

RSI = (Average Gain / Average Loss) x 100

2. Bollinger Bands: Bollinger Bands are volatility bands that consist of a moving average and two standard deviations plotted above and below it. When a stock's price breaks below the lower band, it may be considered oversold. The distance between the bands can be adjusted to suit the trader's preferences.

3. Stochastic Oscillator: The Stochastic Oscillator compares the closing price of a stock to its price range over a given time frame. When the %K line (fast Stochastic) falls below the %D line (slow Stochastic), it may indicate that the stock is oversold.

Front running is a trading practice where a broker or trader executes trades on behalf of a client ahead of the client's order, typically to profit from the price movement created by the client's order.
